mentions.context: The full ImageNet database consists in more than a million images categorized into 1000 different classes.

The custom Python 3 code written for the present project makes use of the following libraries: tensorflow v2.4.1 (Abadi et al., 2015) (using tf.keras API, Chollet et al., 2015), matplotlib v3.3.4 (Hunter, 2007), numpy v1.19.5 (Harris et al., 2020) Since processing cannot increase information (see e.g. Blahut, 1987, pp. 158-159), the information I(µ, r) conveyed by r about µ is at most equal to the one conveyed by the sensory input x, hence we have that C coding ≥ 0. This coding cost tends to zero as noise vanishes.
In this section, we work with the ImageNet dataset (Deng et al., 2009), and more precisely with the subset of images used in the ILSVRC-2010 challenge (Russakovsky et al., 2015).
We made use of the 256x256 model pretrained on ImageNet that is provided by the authors.
Learning is done over 100 epochs through gradient descent using Adam optimizer with default parameters (Kingma and Ba, 2015).
For each trial, learning is done over 50 epochs through gradient descent using Adam optimizer with default parameters (Kingma and Ba, 2015).
For each trial, learning is done over 1000 epochs through gradient descent using Adam optimizer with learning rate 1e-4 (Kingma and Ba, 2015).
Section "Categoricality in deep networks": Evaluation of the categoricality index for the ImageNet experiment.
The network that we consider is the VGG16 model described in Simonyan and Zisserman (2014), which has won the ImageNet Challenge 2014.
The autoencoder is trained with mean square error loss on the full MNIST training set for 1000 epochs, through gradient descent using Adam optimizer (Kingma and Ba, 2015) with learning rate 1e-4.

The custom Python 3 code written for the present project makes use of the following libraries: tensorflow v2.4.1 (Abadi et al., 2015) (using tf.keras API, Chollet et al., 2015), matplotlib v3.3.4 (Hunter, 2007), numpy v1.19.5 (Harris et al., 2020) Since processing cannot increase information (see e.g. Blahut, 1987, pp. 158-159), the information I(µ, r) conveyed by r about µ is at most equal to the one conveyed by the sensory input x, hence we have that C coding ≥ 0. This coding cost tends to zero as noise vanishes.

In Section 3.3 we extend our analysis to very deep networks trained on natural images, working with the Kaggle Dogs vs. Cats dataset, and with the ImageNet dataset (Deng et al., 2009;Russakovsky et al., 2015).

Here, we compare the categoricality index on randomly initialized networks with the exact same architecture, and on a network that has been pretrained on the ImageNet database (as provided by the keras package2 ) (see Materials and Methods for details).

Here, we compare the categoricality index on randomly initialized networks with the exact same architecture, and on a network that has been pretrained on the ImageNet database (as provided by the keras package2 ) (see Materials and Methods for details).

The custom Python 3 code written for the present project makes use of the following libraries: tensorflow v2.4.1 (Abadi et al., 2015) (using tf.keras API, Chollet et al., 2015), matplotlib v3.3.4 (Hunter, 2007), numpy v1.19.5 (Harris et al., 2020) Since processing cannot increase information (see e.g. Blahut, 1987, pp. 158-159), the information I(µ, r) conveyed by r about µ is at most equal to the one conveyed by the sensory input x, hence we have that C coding ≥ 0. This coding cost tends to zero as noise vanishes.

Technically, we compute these distributions thanks to random samples taken either from the same categories or from different categories, and we take as distance between the two distributions the two sample Kolmogorov-Smirnov statistic (using the Python implementation provided by the SciPy package, Virtanen et al., 2020).
